item.title: How to Properly Exit a Program
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

object:

We use System.exit(int) in the application we’re writing at work. One of our GUI menus have two buttons; one for restarting the computer and one for restarting the application. We also have a kill-command that can force us to shutdown. To restart the program, a specific status code is used. Otherwise, 0 represents a graceful shutdown and anything else represents an erroneous shutdown, as the result of an unrecoverable fatal error. Our application (process) should not crash entirely. And no cryptic error messages should be shown to our customers. Although we try to log everything. If that’s not enough, we log a core dump, should the entire application (process) crash.

A desktop application in Java? Damn hippies for real.

Ashi:

I’ve only used System.exit for a forced shutdown. For a proper shutdown you’d just gracefully kill all running threads.

There is nothing graceful about killing a thread.

item.title: How to Properly Exit a Program
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Mopman:

How do you return an error code without using System.exit?

Well, me personally, if an error was to occur I would most likely cause an exception to be thrown using the throws clause… but I guess it’s kinda a situational thing. These conversations never have a linear answer do they, haha. Like for example rather than having something like this:

public static void main(String[] args) { .. // program execution .. // error here System.exit( return code here); }

I would use a flag system and throw an exception accordingly. To reiterate, however, that is my personal style. I just feel that System.exit() is …taboo? in Java

Limits:

But what if you want an option found within the program to stop the running, like pressing the escape key or doing File->Exit

Again, I would use something like this:

public static void main(String[] args) { while(some flag) { //code here .. } }

And then if the person pressed an exit key, I would set the flag to false and allow the JVM to clean up/terminate normally
